Scope 2 company comments: The GHG Protocols Scope 2 Guidance requires that two methods are to be followed in order to calculate scope 2 emissions. The allocation of GHG emissions is completed through using emission factors applied to each unit of energy consumption. The two methods are the location-based method which indicates the average emissions intensity of grids on which energy consumption occurs, while the other is the market-based method which reflects emissions from electricity provided by utility companies. The former uses grid average emission factors while the latter uses supplier-specific emission factors in order to define scope 2 emissions.These two methods together make up the Dual Reporting structure for scope 2 that has become the industry standard for corporations when they report scope 2 emissions. Historically, CRH used only one single emission factor for all types of electricity (purchased non-renewable, purchased renewable and onsite generated renewable) Starting 2016, CRH also follows the Dual Reporting structure of the Greenhouse Gas Protocol, but since the company does not centrally collect product or supplier-specific data from its 3,800 operating locations, it uses only location-based method (U.S. data is on state-based factors given by eGRID while the rest of the world is on the International Energy Agencys grid factors) in order to calculate scope 2 emissions in 2016.
Market based emissions have been calculated but have not been assured.  Both figures have been included for completeness but should not be added together.
